#Text=François du Souhait

#Text=François du Souhait ( between 1570 and 1580 – 1617 in Nancy ) was a French language author ( translator , novelist , poet , satirist , moral philosopher ) of the late 16th and early 17th century from the Duchy of Lorraine ( at the time , a sovereign court with ties to France ) .
#Text=Life
#Text=François du Souhait was born to a noble family in the Champagne region .

#Text=He became " secrétaire ordinaire " to Charles III , Duke of Lorraine ( between 1600 et 1605 ) , and later Henry II , Duke of Lorraine ( from 1608 ) , and several of his works are dedicated to high-ranking members of the Lorraine court , including Princess Catherine of Lorraine and the brothers François de Bassompierre and Je(h)an de Bassompierre .
#Text=Du Souhait lived for many years in France , but he was apparently banished in 1614 for having contributed to a scabrous satirical poetry collection .

#Text=One biographer ( Jean Serroy ) believes that while in France Du Souhait frequented the literary circle around Marguerite de Valois ( through the intervention of his friend , fellow author Jacques Corbin ) .
#Text=Writings

#Text=Du Souhait was the author of seven novels , a collection of short stories ( for which he is today most well-known ) , a collection of poems , a pastoral , a tragedy in 5 acts , a translation of the Iliad , and several works of moral and didactic philosophy .
#Text=Of his seven novels , only his first two seem to have had a certain commercial success ( four editions each , both in Paris and Lyon ) .

#Text=As a novelist , Du Souhait 's early works participated in the same tradition of the " sentimental novel " as authors Antoine de Nervèze and Nicolas des Escuteaux , although Du Souhait differs from these authors both in his content ( he paints a far less idealized portrait of love and includes occasional satirical/realistic elements ) and in his sometimes awkward style ( especially in his " tit-for-tat " gallant dialogues ) .

column1: #Text=Like these other authors , in his later works Du Souhait moved away from the sentimental toward the longer adventurous novel with pastoral elements .
#Text=Du Souhait 's ear for oral discourse and his satirical side are most apparent in his short story collection Histoires comiques ou entretiens facetieux ( Paris , 1612 ) .
#Text=Du Souhait also contributed laudatory poems to the prefatory material of works by Timothée de Chillac and Pierre de Deimier .
#Text=Du Souhait 's seven novels are :
#Text=Les amours de Poliphile et de Mellonimphe ( Lyon , 1599 ) , ( Paris , 1600 ) , ( Lyon , 1605 ) , ( Lyon , 1610 )
#Text=Les amours de Palemon , suitte de Poliphile ( Lyon , 1599 ) , ( Paris , 1600 ) , ( Lyon , 1602 ) , ( Lyon , 1605 )
#Text=Les amours de Glorian et d'Ismene ( Paris , 1600 )
#Text=Les Proprietez d'amour et les propretez des amans , contenant une histoire des amours de Filine et de Polymante ( Paris , 1601 )
#Text=Les Chastes Destinees de Cloris ou le Roman des histoires de ce temps ( Paris , 1609 )
#Text=Le Romant d’Anacrine , où sont representes plusieurs Combats , Histoires veritables & Amoureuses ( Paris , 1613 )

#Text=Le Romant de Gloriande , ou suitte du roman d’Anacrine , où sont continuees les Histoires du premier volume : Avec plusieurs autres nouvelles et force belles avantures ( Paris , 1613 ) , ( Paris , 1630 ) .
